p: Three studies were conducted to examine the in vivo antiviral efficacy and pharmacokinetic behavior of GRFT using various small animal models ( Table 7) [ 41, 46, 47]. Subcutaneous injections of GRFT into guinea pigs and mice were very well tolerated, resulting in the accumulation of GRFT up to relevant therapeutic concentrations [ 41]. The serum from GRFT-treated animals was found to retain antiviral activity against HIV-1-enveloped pseudoviruses in a cell-based neutralization assay [ 41]. In addition, active GRFT, which is capable of neutralizing HIV-Env pseudoviruses, was also detected in rat fecal extracts after chronic oral dosing [ 46]. The in vivo efficacy of GRFT was also demonstrated in the humanized bone marrow-liver-thymus mice which were protected from vaginal infection with HIV-1 after being treated with recombinant C. crescentus expressing GRFT [ 47]. However, GRFT was not orally bioavailable even after chronic treatment [ 46].
